title: How much do writers earn from audiobooks? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, authors do make money from audiobooks. How much will vary. It’s generally a percentage of sales, and places that don’t sell individual titles but instead charge a monthly fee or whatever still have to calculate “sales” for every audiobook downloaded, even if the listeners aren’t paying for them individually. That percentage will vary depending on the exact contract arrangements. Did the publisher license the audiobook, or did the author do it directly? Who paid the narrator? (Sometimes the narrator is paid a flat fee up front; other times the narrator works for a share of the royalties; sometimes it’s a combination.) I’ve honestly lost track of how some of my own contracts are structured, but I do know a couple offhand. In one case, as an example, I hired the narrator myself, there was no up front money involved, and we split the proceeds from ACX/Audible/Amazon evenly. It usually works out to roughly $2 to each of us for every download. (It’s a long book, almost twenty hours.) If there’s a publisher in there, my cut is smaller, but it’s never zero. I mean, why would I allow an audiobook if I wasn’t getting paid for it?
